Q-D5.query: In the warranty, explain how the "coverage start" is defined and what must happen before coverage ends.

v0.response:
## Analysis

### Q1: How is the "coverage start" specifically defined in the warranty?

The Builder's Limited Warranty defines the "coverage start" as follows:

- **Coverage begins on the date of final settlement or the date when the Buyer/Owner first occupies the home, whichever comes first** [10][19][22][27][28][30][31][32][53][55][57][59][61][63][65][70]. This means that the warranty does not wait for both events; it starts as soon as either the final settlement occurs or the owner takes occupancy.
- This definition is consistent across multiple versions of the warranty and is explicitly stated in the "Term" section of the agreement [10][19][22][27][28][30][31][32][53][55][57][59][61][63][65][70].

### Q2: What events, conditions, time limits, or actions must occur before warranty coverage ends, and how are these end-of-coverage triggers described in relation to the defined "coverage start"?

The warranty outlines several triggers and conditions for the end of coverage:

- **Time Limits:** The warranty coverage ends after a specific period from the coverage start:
    - **One (1) year** for major structural components (e.g., floors, ceilings, walls, plumbing, heating, electric wiring, roof) [10][29][30][42][57][63][70].
    - **Sixty (60) days** for certain items (e.g., doors, windows, electric switches, caulking, plumbing fixtures, cabinet work) [10][29][30][42][57][63][70].
    - The warranty explicitly states: "the terms of this Limited Warranty terminate one (1) year or sixty (60) days as applicable after commencement" [10][19][22][27][28][30][31][32][53][55][57][59][61][63][65][70].
- **Claims Must Be Made in Writing Before Expiration:** Any claims must be submitted in writing before the end of the applicable warranty period (one year or sixty days). Claims not made within this period are not covered, regardless of when the defect was discovered [10][19][22][27][28][30][31][32][53][55][57][59][61][63][65][70].
- **Transfer of Ownership:** The warranty is **not transferable**. If the original Buyer/Owner sells the home or moves out, the warranty automatically terminates, even if the time period has not expired [10][19][22][27][28][30][31][32][53][55][57][59][61][63][65][70].
- **Exclusions and Other Termination Events:** The warranty lists several exclusions (e.g., damage from abuse, neglect, acts of God, defects in items not installed by the Builder, etc.) that, if applicable, mean the warranty does not cover those issues, but these do not affect the general time-based termination [10][19][22][27][28][30][31][32][53][55][57][59][61][63][65][70].

**Relation to Coverage Start:**  
The end-of-coverage triggers (expiration of one year or sixty days, sale or move-out by the original owner) are all measured from the coverage start date, which is the earlier of final settlement or first occupancy [10][19][22][27][28][30][31][32][53][55][57][59][61][63][65][70].

## Key Connections

- The **definition of coverage start** (final settlement or first occupancy, whichever comes first) is the reference point for all warranty periods.
- The **end of coverage** is strictly tied to elapsed time from the coverage start (one year or sixty days), or to a change in ownership/occupancy, whichever comes first.
- **Claims must be made within the applicable period** from the coverage start; otherwise, they are not covered.
- The **non-transferability** of the warranty means that the warranty is personal to the original owner and ceases if the property is sold or the owner moves out, regardless of the time elapsed since coverage start.

## Conclusion

**In the Builder's Limited Warranty, the "coverage start" is defined as the earlier of the date of final settlement or the date when the Buyer/Owner first occupies the home. Warranty coverage ends when either the applicable time period (one year for major components, sixty days for certain items) has elapsed from the coverage start, or when the original owner sells or moves out of the home, whichever comes first. Additionally, any claims must be made in writing before the end of the applicable period, or they are not covered. These end-of-coverage triggers are all measured in direct relation to the defined coverage start.** [10][19][22][27][28][30][31][32][53][55][57][59][61][63][65][70]
